summary: A video exploring the realities of safety in Brazil while promoting its tourism and addressing common stereotypes.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey, sitting in a room with a globe, flowers, and a clapperboard on the wall behind him. He speaks directly to the camera, discussing stereotypes about Brazil and his experiences as a traveler. Text appears on the screen in Portuguese, translating to "If you have seen my other videos, you know that I like to ask foreigners what they know about Brazil." He mentions that stereotypes about Brazil are common among Europeans and North Americans, often focusing on football, beaches, beautiful women, and carnival. The man then shares his approach to travel, emphasizing the importance of safety and exploring unfamiliar areas. The scene transitions to a picturesque beach with turquoise water and sandy shores, accompanied by text expressing his desire to share his experiences living and traveling in Brazil. The video concludes with two men in a market, one eating and the other looking at him, with text highlighting the country's size and the relatively low number of international tourists it receives annually.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an upbeat, energetic intro featuring a male speaker starting with "What's up guys?". He mentions frequent questions from non-Brazilians about safety while visiting Brazil. He shares his experience of asking non-Brazilians what they think or know about Brazil. He notes that stereotypes like soccer, beaches, beautiful women, and Carnival are universal. He addresses violence and crime, something he always considers before visiting a country. He hopes to share tips from his experiences living and traveling in Brazil, encouraging others to visit. The audio ends with a subtle background music with a jazzy rhythm on piano.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation (CBF) logo is seated in a room with a homely atmosphere. The background features a shelf with decorative items, a clapperboard, and a framed picture. The man appears to be speaking, as indicated by his hand gestures and facial expressions. On-screen text in Portuguese reads, "Eu vou falar sobre alguns dos estereótipos negativos que eu ouvi sobre o Brasil," which translates to "I will talk about some of the negative stereotypes I have heard about Brazil." The man continues to speak, and the text changes to, "Se alguém viu os filmes 'Cidade de Deus' ou 'Tropa de Elite' eles têm uma ideia gloriosa do que como o Brasil é," meaning "If someone has seen the movies 'City of God' or 'Elite Squad,' they have a glorious idea of what Brazil is." The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is discussing the impact of these films on perceptions of Brazil. The setting remains consistent throughout the video, with no significant changes in the environment or the man's attire.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating he's going to go over "negative stereotypes...about Brazil," mentioning films like "City of God" and "Elite Squad" that give a "glorified idea" of Brazilian cities. He speaks in a conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey, speaking in a room adorned with various decorations, including a clapperboard and a shelf with framed items. The text on the screen reads, "Em todas as grandes cidades e até mesmo em cidades de 100.000 pessoas, sempre haverá favelas" (In all big cities and even in cities of 100,000 people, there will always be favelas). The scene transitions to an outdoor setting where a man in a blue shirt and a yellow cap is seen performing a ritual with a large, decorated statue, surrounded by lush greenery. The text remains the same, emphasizing the ubiquity of favelas. The next scene shows a densely packed neighborhood with colorful houses, accompanied by the text, "São áreas onde as pessoas constroem casas improvisadas e vivem lá" (They are areas where people build improvised houses and live there). The video then shifts to a bustling street with shops and people walking, with the text, "Fazem parte de todas as cidades mas como turista e seguindo minhas dicas..." (They are part of all cities but as a tourist and following my tips...). The final scene features a vibrant mural of a clown on a colorful wall, with the text, "Você não terá uma interação com essas áreas. Talvez você as passe na estrada" (You will not have an interaction with these areas. Maybe you will pass by them on the road). The video wraps up with the man in the yellow jersey reappearing, with the text, "Mas você não vai encontrar uma situação em que você está em uma favela em perigo" (But you will not find a situation where you are in a favela in danger).
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing favelas in Brazilian cities, explaining their prevalence and the likelihood of tourists interacting with them. His tone is informative and somewhat reassuring. Then, the audio ends abruptly.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a room decorated with various items, including a globe, a clapperboard, and a shelf with a plant and a framed letter 'P'. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, and subtitles in Portuguese appear at the bottom of the screen, translating his words into English. The subtitles read: "I had the chance to visit one of the most famous favelas in the country this year," "It has become more touristy to visit these communities in big cities," "We hired a tour guide and went with some of the community members," "We visited the community center and saw some of the positive events in the community," "This opened my eyes to the fact that yes, most of the drug activities happen there...," "But most people are just living a normal life," and "If you are interested in this type of experience, these options are available." The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is sharing a personal experience and insights about visiting a favela, emphasizing the positive aspects of the community and the availability of such experiences for others.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a single male speaker describing visiting a favela in Sao Paulo, stating it's become "more touristic". He continues, describing hiring a tour guide and going with local residents, visiting the community center and witnessing positive activities. The speaker notes drug activity is associated with favelas, but there are also "communities of people who are just living normal lives", and that visiting a favela in Rio or Sao Paulo is an option.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with a globe, a plant, and framed pictures, creating a homely atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. On-screen text in Portuguese appears, translating to "Some Brazilians who know don't like this type of tourism" and "A Brazilian told me it's like going to a zoo to see the animals while you drive." He continues, sharing his experience of interviewing a young man from the community who is becoming a doctor and wants to give back to the community. The text reads, "But my experience was enlightening. I interviewed a young man from there who is becoming a doctor and wants to give back to the community." The man encourages viewers to learn more about the community in a safe way, with the text stating, "If you are interested in seeing how it is, there are safe ways to go and see it." He concludes by acknowledging that not everyone agrees with this type of tourism, as the text reads, "But know that not everyone agrees with this type of tourism." Throughout the video, the man's expressions and gestures convey his passion and enthusiasm for the topic, engaging the audience with his personal insights and experiences.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker discussing tourism in Brazil, mentioning that some Brazilians disagree with it, comparing it to "a fishbowl" and "animals in a zoo." He shares an anecdote about a young man from the favela becoming a doctor and wanting to give back to the community. He suggests there are safe ways to visit the favelas, while acknowledging not everyone agrees with the practice of tourism there. The speaker then shifts to the topic of street crime in Brazil.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo is seen speaking directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with a globe, a framed picture, and a clapperboard, along with a vase of flowers on a table, creating a homely atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. On-screen text in Portuguese appears, translating to "Sometimes in the USA I see a post or report about a video of a car theft or robbery. It becomes a meme that the video must be from Brazil." The man continues to speak, and more text appears, stating, "When it seems to be from South America due to the clothes and cars. And always someone says it must be in Brazil." The final text reads, "These videos are always from Brazil," reinforcing the man's point about the stereotype that such videos are from Brazil. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere throughout, with the man's gestures and the on-screen text providing a coherent narrative about the cultural perception of Brazilian videos.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of one male speaker who is describing a common internet meme. He talks about how videos of attempted robberies or carjackings often lead to comments suggesting the incident occurred in Brazil, even when the location isn't immediately obvious. His tone is conversational and somewhat informal.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with a globe, a plant, and framed pictures, creating a homely atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. On-screen text in Portuguese appears, translating to "For many people, this is the only contact they have with Brazilian culture by watching these videos..." and "On YouTube or Reddit or Facebook. And they don't understand the reality of what Brazil really is." He continues, sharing his personal experience of living in Brazil for 14 months without encountering the type of violence often depicted in media. The text reads, "I lived in Brazil for 14 months and never saw this type of violence. I was never robbed or mugged. I know people who have been." He further clarifies that he knows people from the USA who have also been robbed, and that such incidents occur in Brazil, as well as in other large cities around the world. The text states, "But I also know people from the USA who have been robbed. It happens in Brazil, but it also happens here and in Europe or any large city with many people." The man's expressions and gestures convey a sense of personal experience and a desire to correct misconceptions about Brazil.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker, conveying a conversational tone as he refers to Brazilian culture, "for a lot of people," and then describes his personal experience of living in Brazil for "14 months." He notes that he never witnessed violence of any kind, even though he knows people who have been robbed or had their homes broken into.  He then asserts that these things happen anywhere, including in the United States and Europe. The clip concludes with the male speaker saying, "anywhere else in the world that has big cities and lots of people."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo is seated in a room with a neutral-colored wall adorned with various decorative items, including a globe, a flower arrangement, and a clapperboard. The man appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. The text on the screen is in Portuguese, with the first line reading "Viajar para as cidades da Europa me ensinou a estar atento ao que está acontecendo ao meu redor," which translates to "Traveling to European cities taught me to be attentive to what is happening around me." The second line of text states, "Em Barcelona e Londres há um problema com o furto, então você deve sempre prestar atenção," meaning "In Barcelona and London, there is a problem with theft, so you must always pay attention." The final line of text reads, "É a mesma ideia no Brasil, mas você precisa ser um pouco mais atento," which translates to "It's the same idea in Brazil, but you need to be a little more attentive." The man's expressions and the text suggest he is discussing the importance of being vigilant in different environments, particularly in cities with higher rates of theft. The setting remains consistent throughout the video, with no significant changes in the background or the man's position.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male voice speaks with a thoughtful tone about traveling in big cities in Europe, emphasizing the need to "be very mindful of your surroundings" due to issues like pickpocketing in places like "Barcelona" and "London." He then compares this to the situation in "Brazil," saying it's "maybe a little bit more heightened."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a room decorated with various items, including a globe, a clapperboard, and framed pictures. The man, who has short dark hair, gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. Throughout the video, text appears at the bottom of the screen in Portuguese, providing advice on personal safety. The text reads: "O conselho que dou aos meus amigos e familiares é que se você não precisa usar o celular, coloque-o no bolso" (The advice I give to my friends and family is that if you don't need to use your cell phone, put it in your pocket), "Isso faz com que você tenha menos chances de se tornar um alvo" (This makes it less likely for you to become a target), "Como eu disse nada aconteceu comigo, mas eu conheço pessoas que perderam seus celulares na rua e os ladrões saem correndo" (As I said, nothing happened to me, but I know people who lost their cell phones on the street and the thieves ran away), "Mas esse tipo de crime existe na Ásia também" (But this type of crime also exists in Asia), "É algo que eu estou acostumado como viajante e se vocês estão pensando em visitar o Brasil, provavelmente já viajou para outros países também" (It's something I'm used to as a traveler and if you're thinking of visiting Brazil, you've probably traveled to other countries too), and "Então vocês já sabem estar atentos ao seu entorno" (So you already know to be aware of your surroundings). The man's expressions and gestures change slightly as he speaks, conveying a sense of urgency and personal experience. The background remains consistent, with the room's decor providing a casual and personal atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker shares advice given to visitors in Brazil, suggesting they keep phones in their pockets to avoid becoming targets for theft. His tone is casual and conversational. He mentions that nothing like that has happened to him, but he has heard stories. He expands the topic to similar experiences in Asia, reminding listeners to be mindful of their surroundings while traveling. He concludes by mentioning walking on streets.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with a globe, a plant, and a clapperboard, creating a casual and inviting atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. On-screen text in Portuguese appears, providing context to his speech. The text reads: "Falando em andar na rua, vamos imaginar que você chega no Rio e é a sua primeira noite" (Talking about walking on the street, let's imagine you arrive in Rio and it's your first night), followed by "Você está animado e quer andar por lá. Se você estiver hospedado numa área turística, pode ir na recepção do hotel e perguntar se é seguro explorar o bairro" (You are excited and want to walk around. If you are staying in a tourist area, you can go to the hotel reception and ask if it is safe to explore the neighborhood). The man continues to speak, and the text changes to "É uma sensação geral de saber onde você está e o que está fazendo" (It is a general feeling of knowing where you are and what you are doing), followed by "A menos que você esteja planejando chegar e apenas vagando pela cidade sem destino, você estará bem" (Unless you are planning to arrive and just wandering around the city without a destination, you will be fine). The man shares his personal experiences, mentioning "Eu visitei o Rio de Janeiro e Foz de Iguaçu que tem algumas cachoeiras lindas" (I visited Rio de Janeiro and Foz de Iguaçu, which has some beautiful waterfalls), and concludes with "Eu acho que elas são 7 vezes maiores do que as Cataratas do Niágara. E um lugar incrível" (I think they are 7 times bigger than the Niagara Falls. And an incredible place). The final text reads: "Essa é a melhor coisa a fazer. No Rio você pode fazer um tour de Cristo Redentor e Pão de Açúcar no mesmo dia" (This is the best thing to do. In Rio, you can do a tour of Christ the Redeemer and Sugarloaf Mountain on the same day). The man's engaging demeanor and the informative text provide a helpful guide for tourists
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker initiating a hypothetical scenario about arriving in Rio, emphasizing excitement and suggesting seeking advice from hotel staff about safety. He highlights the importance of general awareness, making informed decisions as a savvy traveler, such as considering taxis at night instead of walking. He then recommends booking tours and mentions attractions like Christ the Redeemer and Pão de Açúcar. He also references visiting Foz do Iguaçu, emphasizing its waterfalls and suggesting a tour guide for the best experience.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with various decorative items, including a globe, a plant, and framed pictures, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, emphasizing his points. On-screen text in Portuguese appears, providing context to his discussion about traveling in Brazil. The text reads: "E não é muito caro. Outra razão eu amo viajar no Brasil é que é acessível" (And it's not very expensive. Another reason I love traveling in Brazil is that it's affordable), "Se você é dos EUA ou da Europa, é mais barato viajar no Brasil do que é nesses lugares" (If you are from the USA or Europe, it is cheaper to travel in Brazil than in those places), "A taxa de câmbio é boa para pessoas com dólares ou euros" (The exchange rate is good for people with dollars or euros), "No Rio, contratamos um guia turístico para o dia e incluiu alimentos e transporte por cerca de US $ 100" (In Rio, we hired a tour guide for the day and included food and transportation for about US $ 100), and "Turismo no Brasil é acessível para que você possa fazer muito com um guia turístico e não pagar uma fortuna" (Tourism in Brazil is affordable so that you can do a lot with a tour guide and not pay a fortune). The man's expressions and gestures, along with the informative text, convey his enthusiasm and practical advice about the affordability and benefits of traveling in Brazil.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining that traveling in Brazil is relatively inexpensive, especially for those from the United States or Europe, because their money goes further there. He notes that the exchange rate is favorable for those using dollars or euros, giving an example of hiring a tour guide for a day, including transportation and food, for around 100 dollars per person in Rio. He emphasizes that tourism in Brazil is reasonably priced, allowing visitors to experience a lot with a tour guide without spending a fortune. Finally, there's the sound of a deep "ugh" followed by silence.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim is seated in a room adorned with various decorations, including a globe, a flower arrangement, and framed pictures on the wall. He appears to be speaking directly to the camera, sharing advice about traveling in Portugal. The text on the screen reads, "Outra dica para vocês é não usar o Airbnb. Especialmente se você não fala Português," which translates to "Another tip for you is not to use Airbnb. Especially if you don't speak Portuguese." He continues to speak, and the text changes to, "Na minha experiência com o Airbnb no Brasil, nem todos os anfitriões falam inglês," meaning "In my experience with Airbnb in Brazil, not all the hosts speak English." The man gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The text then changes to, "Então, se você precisa perguntar por direções ou sobre o bairro ou por dicas, é mais difícil fazer," which translates to "So, if you need to ask for directions or about the neighborhood or for tips, it's more difficult to do." Finally, the text reads, "Os hotéis sempre terão alguém que fale inglês e possam ajudá-lo a encontrar passeios e tudo," meaning "Hotels will always have someone who speaks English and can help you find tours and everything." The man continues to speak, providing further advice on traveling in Portugal, with the consistent background and decorations throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features one male speaker, who is sharing general travel tips. He advises against using Airbnb, especially for first-timers who don't speak Portuguese, because hotel staff are more likely to speak English and provide assistance with directions and tour arrangements, making them a better option. He speaks in a conversational and informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim and the Brazil Football Confederation logo speaks directly to the camera in a cozy, well-decorated room. The background features a shelf with a globe, a plant, and a framed clapperboard, creating a homely atmosphere. The man gestures with his hands as he discusses accommodations, specifically highlighting the benefits of staying in "pousadas," which are a mix of bed-and-breakfast and resort-style accommodations. He mentions that these places typically have around 10 to 15 rooms, a reception, a bar, and a restaurant, and are picturesque with excellent customer service. The man shares that some of the best Brazilian meals he has had came from these pousadas across the country. He concludes by recommending staying in pousadas and hotels instead of Airbnbs. Throughout the video, text appears on the screen in Portuguese, providing translations and context for his recommendations.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker describing "posadas," which he compares to bed and breakfasts mixed with resorts in Brazil. He says that the customer service is amazing and some of the best meals he's had have been in posadas and then recommends posadas and hotels over Airbnb. The speaker then concludes by saying Brazil is an incredible place with incredible people. The tone is upbeat and positive throughout.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person wearing a yellow Brazil football jersey with green trim, speaking directly to the camera in a room decorated with various items such as a globe, a clapperboard, and a shelf with plants and framed pictures. The individual gestures with their hands while delivering a message about Brazil, with subtitles in Portuguese appearing at the bottom of the screen. The subtitles read: "Mas o Brasil é um país incrível com pessoas incríveis" (But Brazil is an incredible country with incredible people), "Espero que todos tenham aprendido algumas dicas sobre como viajar pelo Brasil" (I hope everyone has learned some tips on how to travel around Brazil), and "E espero ter convencido você de que é um lugar seguro para visitar" (And I hope I have convinced you that it is a safe place to visit). The scene then transitions to a black background with a wooden texture, displaying the text "MAIS UM VÍDEO?" (MORE VIDEOS?) at the top, an Instagram logo with the handle "bro_x" in the center, and "INSCREVA-SE" (SUBSCRIBE) at the bottom, encouraging viewers to follow the Instagram account and subscribe for more content.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker who is expressing hope that his audience has learned something about Brazil and is convinced it is safe and worth visiting. He speaks in a friendly and encouraging tone. Following this, there is upbeat, instrumental music that sounds like it could be from a travel vlog. The music is light and cheerful, creating a positive vibe.
